stream_context.summary: Debugging a crash in Course 15’s snowflake particle system, followed by performance-oriented level edits and a design pivot away from a styrofoam ground effect. Kaze alternates between low-level assembly debugging and broad art/level layout tweaks while chatting about emulation woes, release questions, and monetisation.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 is “getting close to completion,” but a crash tied to its snowflake particle effect blocks progress. The bug appears only on certain emulators; real N64 hardware runs fine.
development_findings.quote: It works on N64 as well… this is just a mess.

development_findings.summary: Root cause investigation revealed a missing ×4 in the vertex-buffer size calculation, leading to memory corruption; fixing that stopped degenerate vertices but Project64 still crashed, implying an emulator quirk.
development_findings.quote: It’s like it’s missing the multiply by 4 here… that mystery is solved, but that wouldn’t have caused the crash though.

development_findings.summary: Inlining vs. non-inlining one function changes codegen enough to stop the Project64 crash, confirming an emulator-specific bug rather than bad game code.
development_findings.quote: How does changing the function from an inline to not an inline make it work? This garbage emulator man, I swear.

development_findings.summary: While examining the bug, Kaze implemented an optimisation that pre-caches vertex comments, lowering CPU time to ~12 ms; RDP overdraw (≈40 ms) is now the main bottleneck.
Styrofoam normal-mapped ground causes visual issues and adds overdraw; decision made to scrap it in favour of flat cardboard with stapled paper, suggested by Biobak.
development_findings.quote: Do we even want the normal-map styrofoam? I don’t think it does [look good]… Replace styrofoam with cardboard and paper staple.

development_findings.summary: Additional micro-design tasks completed: added zipper portal to “hell,” balanced two tilting bridges, placed a safety spring, and flagged missing assets (Peach doodle, Bowser noodle, two walls).
Implemented googly-eye physics on cardboard Luigi; eye movement parameters (gravity, damping) exposed for polish.
Field-of-view system includes a 16:9 toggle that widens view while cropping sides; anti-aliasing toggle costs ~15 % performance.
Target ROM size is 64 MB; current build uses RGBA32 textures with optional mip-maps (only where the combiner can afford them).

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s main paid job is corporate programming; ROM-hack work is a monetised hobby relying on streams, videos, and ad revenue.
context_findings.quote: If it was up to me I just wouldn’t make videos at all, but then I can’t do my thing as a hobby that makes money.

context_findings.summary: Power flickers and poor local infrastructure repeatedly disrupt streams, causing frustration about lost viewers.
context_findings.quote: I’m so pissed… Whenever that happens, your view count just drops back to zero.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy on performance vs. visuals: willing to cut side-pixels or fancy effects for +10 FPS; prefers bigger FOV over perfect widescreen.
context_findings.quote: I think I’m allowed to cut off a little bit on the side if it means you go from 20 FPS to 30 FPS.

context_findings.summary: Marketing self-image: calls RTYI the “first quadruple-A N64 game.”
context_findings.quote: That’s going to be the marketing—first quadruple A N64 game ever.

context_findings.summary: Tentative price point is $10–20; will do market research before deciding.

biobak.summary: Proposed replacing costly styrofoam normal-map ground with simpler cardboard + paper stapled surface and adding rim shading gradient; Kaze accepted.
biobak.quote: I like the idea you posted… Replace styrofoam with cardboard and paper staple.

biobak.summary: Suggested bubble-wrap mini-puzzle (pop nine bubbles for Yoshi coin).

zeina.summary: A friend of Zeina installed the N64-Digital HDMI mod on Kaze’s console; Zeina otherwise not present in this stream.

key_stories.title: Snowflake Crash Saga
key_stories.summary: Particle snowflakes in Course 15 crash Project64 but not real hardware. Kaze traces vertex-buffer math, fixes a ×4 error, and discovers the emulator still crashes unless a function is non-inlined, revealing an emulator quirk.
key_stories.challenge: Unreliable crashes tied to snowflakes on some emulators.
key_stories.process: Debugged assembly, inspected memory, adjusted buffer maths, toggled inlining.
key_stories.outcome: Game stable on hardware; partial emulator workaround in place, long-term fix deferred.
key_stories.key_quote: It works on N64; this garbage emulator just hates my inline function.

key_stories.title: Styrofoam Ground Pivot
key_stories.summary: Original plan used a normal-mapped styrofoam surface for the craft world, but it looked off and caused performance issues. Biobak suggested a cardboard floor with stapled paper and smooth rim gradient.
key_stories.challenge: Unattractive visuals and RDP cost from styrofoam effect.
key_stories.process: On-stream discussion; tested grass-only normal-map; evaluated alternatives.
key_stories.outcome: Team will scrap styrofoam and implement cardboard/paper solution.
key_stories.key_quote: Do we even want the normal-map styrofoam? I don’t think it does.

key_stories.title: Balancing the Tilting Bridges
key_stories.summary: Two narrow, tilting paper bridges felt too hard. Kaze slowed their motion and tested them with latency, ensuring casual players can cross while skilled players can still shortcut.
key_stories.process: Adjusted speed variables, live-tested, added optional spring safety.
key_stories.outcome: Final parameters ‘feel good’; both bridges marked finished.
key_stories.key_quote: That does feel good—I like it.

open_questions.topic: Final ground treatment for craft sky area
open_questions.context: Three options debated: white void, ocean texture, or table surface. No decision reached, only agreement to remove styrofoam.
